MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Student Nurses Fees.

Qst.Quest: if he will abolish the undergraduate fee for nurses.

if he will abolish the fees for students of the bachelor of nursing degree course due to commence in January 1998 in view of the fact that they will be the only day undergraduates in the country paying fees; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

whether he acknowledges that nursing students attending the one year degree course are the only full-time undergraduate students attending college whose course are not exempt from fees; whether he would extend such exemption to the nursing undergraduate degree course and provide higher education maintenance grants to nurses to undertake this course; whether he agrees that the position of such nurses is similar to teachers who undertake the higher diploma in education; and whether he will give full recognition to the substantial benefits to the health service in encouraging qualified nurses to take the one year degree course.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 917, 941 and 942 together.

MainHeading.P: As Deputies are aware, a revised programme for basic pre-registration nurse education and training was introduced in October, 1994 on a pilot basis and has since been extended to a large number of nursing schools in association with local higher education institutions. The programme is funded by the Department of Health, at a cost of some £13 million in 1997. Accordingly, the question of student fees for the diploma programme does not arise. Successful completion of the three year programme leads to a Diploma in Nursing Studies and students are eligible to register with An Bord Altranais for employment as a nurse.

The position in relation to the continuing education of nurses is that the Department of Health has been engaged in consultations with a number of third level institutions in relation to the development of accessible degree programmes which would be open both to nurses who complete the new education and training programme and to nurses who qualified under the traditional model of education and training. The purpose of these programmes is to provide those members of the nursing profession who wish to obtain a post-registration qualification at degree level with an opportunity to do so by means of a one year part-time programme. The first such programme was offered by Dublin City University earlier this year and I understand that Trinity College Dublin propose to offer a similar part-time programme from February, 1998. These programmes are provided on a self-financing basis and the nurses involved can claim tax relief on their fees or can apply to their relevant health agency for assistance from the funding provided by the Department of Health for the continuing education of registered nurses.

A one year full-time degree course leading to a bachelor of nursing has commenced this month in the National University of Ireland, Galway. When the Higher Education Authority became aware of the proposal to introduce this course, it had discussions with the National University of Ireland, Galway and asked the univerity to align its proposal with the approach adopted in the other colleges. Earlier this month, the university advised the Higher Education Authority of its intention to proceed with the course and I understand that 51 students have enrolled on the course. In view of these developments and the likely consequences for nursing education generally, my Department is currently engaged in further discussions on the matter with the Department of Health and the Higher Education Authority. I will advise the Deputies as to the outcome of these discussions as soon as possible. In relation to the specific points raised by the Deputies, I would like to clarify that these students are not the only full-time undergratute students attending college whose course is not exempt from fees. The free fees initiative applies to full-time undergraduate courses which must generally be of at least two years duration. The position in relation to the higher diploma in education course is that it is a postgraduate course whereas this course is an undergraduate course.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if, following the awarding of higher education grants, the subsequent payment of a personal injury award will affect the student's eligibility for the grant; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Compensation paid as a result of a personal injury award is not assessable as reckonable income for the purpose of the higher education grants scheme, except where the award includes a payment for loss of earnings in respect of the year of assessment in which case the payment is assessable as reckonable income.
Interest earned on investments, including personal injury awards which are invested, is also assessed as reckonable income.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: if he will confirm that free third level fees apply to mature students in full-time third level education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Under the free fees initiative, tuition fees are payable in respect of eligible students, including eligible mature students, who are attending approved full-time undergratuate courses, which must generally be of at least two years duration, at approved third level institutions.

Qst.Quest: when he will announce the names of the seven nominees to the Tipperary Rural Business Development Institute; and when the Tipperary Rural Business Development Institute Company is to be established.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Matters concerning the composition of the board of TRBDI and the establishment of the institute as a limited liability company are under consideration at present and the necessary actions will be taken as soon as possible.

Qst.Quest: if a college (details supplied), will be recognised for grant purposes in the academic year 1997-98 in view of the fact that it is providing courses covered in a number of other northern colleges; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: BTEC Higher National Diploma or equivalent level courses offered at approved colleges in Northern Ireland are recognised for the purposes of the vocational education committees' scholarship schemes.

No application has been received from the college in question for recognition of BTEC Higher National Diploma or equivalent level courses for this purpose. Any application made to my Department for such recognition would be considered.

Qst.Quest: the current status in relation to a school extension (details supplied); when tenders will be opened; the timescale for actual building; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Tenders are currently being evaluated within my Department for the proposed extension at the school referred to by the Deputy. Subject to the satisfactory completion of this process and the lodgment of the local contribution, a contract can then be awarded and works can begin on site. At this point, it is not possible for me to give a precise date for commencement of work on site. However, I expect that works should begin within the next few weeks. My Department will keep in touch with the school on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if there is an assigned number of hours for music in the recommended timetable at primary and secondary level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: In primary schools it is the responsibility of the principal teacher, in consultation with the school staff, to outline a plan of work for the school as a whole and to ensure that each area of the primary curriculum is adequately dealt with in all classes. The time recommended for the teaching of music is approximately one hour per week.
It should be noted that the time spent on the different aspects of the primary curriculum would vary somewhat between pupils in junior classes and those in senior classes.

In second level schools, the minimum recommended timetable requirement is three forty-minute class periods per week in each of the three years of the junior cycle. In the case of leaving certificate music, it is recommended that not less than three hours per week be made available in each of the two leaving certificate years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton

Speaker.P: Music forms part of the curriculum in primary schools as laid out in the primary school curriculum handbook. All primary schools offer music as a subject to be taken by all pupils.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he is taking to facilitate the opening of a new second level Gaelscoil on the northside of Dublin from September 1998.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to my reply to Question No. 128, on Wednesday, 10 December 1997. In that reply, I indicated that a review of the need for all Irish postprimary facilities in the Dublin north each area was being carried out by the planning section of my Department in the light of all relevant factors, such as the adequacy of existing provision, demographic trends and likely future demand.
This review is now well advanced and I expect that a report and recommendation in the matter will be submitted to me for consideration very shortly.

Qst.Quest: if he will confer disadvantaged status on a primary school in Dublin north east (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: The school in question is one of a number of schools which have applied to my Department for disadvantaged status.

The disadvantaged areas scheme has not been extended at all for three years, and in these cases for capitation purposes only. As an alternative to a further widening of the scheme, and following in-depth studies of educational disadvantage conducted by the Education Research Centre and the Combat Poverty Agency, a new pilot project, the Breaking the Cycle pilot project, was launched in May 1996.
I am currently reviewing overall provision to combat educational disadvantage. I assure the Deputy that the needs of the school in question will be considered in the context of this review.

Qst.Quest: the current position in regard to the provision of the new girls post-primary school at Celbridge, County Kildare; the number of places likely to be provided; a schedule of the facilities; if his Department will now allow the project to proceed to the next stage in the planning and development process; if he will further state when he expects actual construction work to start on the site; the availability of the necessary funds to meet such contingencies in the current year; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: The new girls post-primary school at Celbridge, County Kildare will cater for an enrolment of 800 pupils. The building unit of my Department has recently approved stage 3 (developed sketch scheme) of the architectural planning progress and the design team are currently preparing combined stages 4/5 (detailed design/bill of quantities) for submission to the Department.
Pre-selection of qualified tenderers for the construction of the school is currently taking place. Construction will commence as soon as architectural planning and tendering have been completed.

Qst.Quest: the current position in relation to the extra facilities sought at Scoil Mhuire, Clane, County Kildare; the degree to which agreement has been reached between his Department and the school authorities in regards to the facilities required; those likely to be provided; whether he proposes to allow the project go to tender in the near future; if, in view of the urgent need for extra facilities, he will facilitate an early start on contract work by way of special financial provision for this purpose in the current year; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Stage 2 documentation (outline sketch scheme) is currently being examined by the building unit of my Department and a decision on this stage is expected shortly. A schedule of accommodation has previously been agreed between the Department and the school authorities.

As this project is in the early stage of architectural planning, it is too early to say when construction will commence. The question of funding being made available for the project will only arise when construction has started.

Qst.Quest: the assistance which exists towards transport or other costs associated with a person (details supplied) in County Kildare whose son is dyslexic and has to attend special classes in Newbridge, County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
